title: Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer: Detected early, highly curable
abstract:
Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer is an early stage of cancer. If treatment is followed, the 5-year survival rate is over 82% when the tumor is still in place.
  The incidence of nasopharyngeal cancer in men is 3 times higher than in women. The disease is most common in South China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Vietnam, Philippines, North Africa, the Middle East...
 A diet rich in salted fish and salted meat contributes to an increased risk of disease. The reason is that salted foods, when undergoing fermentation, can produce toxins such as nitrosamine. This is a carcinogen. A diet rich in grains, fruits, vegetables and low in milk helps reduce the risk of this disease.
 Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is considered a risk factor for nasopharyngeal cancer (nasopharyngeal cancer) and is common in children and adolescents. The group of nasopharyngeal cancers with non-keratinizing and undifferentiated pathology is often reported to be infected with EBV. EBV DNA is found in nasopharyngeal cancer cells, pre-cancerous cells and in the blood of patients.
 However, EBV infection alone is not enough to cause nasopharyngeal cancer. The combination of other factors such as each person's genetic characteristics, exposure to tobacco, etc. can affect the body's response to EBV, thereby promoting the development of nasopharyngeal cancer.
 Infection with some types of HPV virus increases the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer, such as Human Papilloma virus. The risk of nasopharyngeal cancer increases with HPV infection in young people under 30 years old, especially in smokers.
 Smoking and drinking alcohol increase the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer. Cigarettes contain carcinogens, and they can also increase the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer by reactivating the EBV virus.
content:
Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer: Detected early, highly curable

Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer is an early stage of cancer. If treatment is followed, the 5-year survival rate is over 82% when the tumor is still in place.
  The incidence of nasopharyngeal cancer in men is 3 times higher than in women. The disease is most common in South China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Vietnam, Philippines, North Africa, the Middle East...
 A diet rich in salted fish and salted meat contributes to an increased risk of disease. The reason is that salted foods, when undergoing fermentation, can produce toxins such as nitrosamine. This is a carcinogen. A diet rich in grains, fruits, vegetables and low in milk helps reduce the risk of this disease.
 Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is considered a risk factor for nasopharyngeal cancer (nasopharyngeal cancer) and is common in children and adolescents. The group of nasopharyngeal cancers with non-keratinizing and undifferentiated pathology is often reported to be infected with EBV. EBV DNA is found in nasopharyngeal cancer cells, pre-cancerous cells and in the blood of patients.
 However, EBV infection alone is not enough to cause nasopharyngeal cancer. The combination of other factors such as each person's genetic characteristics, exposure to tobacco, etc. can affect the body's response to EBV, thereby promoting the development of nasopharyngeal cancer.
 Infection with some types of HPV virus increases the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer, such as Human Papilloma virus. The risk of nasopharyngeal cancer increases with HPV infection in young people under 30 years old, especially in smokers.
 Smoking and drinking alcohol increase the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer. Cigarettes contain carcinogens, and they can also increase the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer by reactivating the EBV virus.

What is stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer?
Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer is the earliest stage of nasopharyngeal cancer, also known as carcinoma in situ (CIS).
Nasopharynx cancer is a type of cancer that originates in the nasopharynx (nasopharynx is the area located at the top of the throat, behind the nasal cavity and near the base of the skull, connecting the nose with the lower part of the throat).
At stage 0, the tumor is only limited to the surface layer, has not grown deeper, and cancer cells have not metastasized to lymph nodes and distant organs.
Based on the TNM staging system of the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC), nasopharyngeal cancer is divided into stages 0-4. Among them, stage 0 is the earliest stage.
Image of the nasopharynx. Source: depositphotos.com
Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer has the following characteristics: (1)
Tumor (T: Tumor): The letter “T” plus a number (0 to 4) is used to evaluate the size of the tumor and the degree of invasion of structures around the tumor.; Tis: Carcinoma in situ.; Node (N: Node): The letter “N” in the TNM classification system is used to evaluate metastatic lymph nodes. Lymph nodes near the original tumor site are called regional lymph nodes. Lymph nodes outside the regional lymph node area are classified as distant metastases.
For people with nasopharyngeal cancer, doctors will check the lymph nodes in the neck on both sides, including the lymph nodes under the chin, under the jaw, behind the neck, behind the ear, along the sternocleidomastoid muscle and lymph nodes. on the blow.
N0 (N zero): No regional lymph node metastasis; Metastasis (M): The letter “M” in the TNM system indicates whether there has been distant metastasis to other organs; M0 (M zero): Cancer has not spread to other parts of the body.
Thus, stage 0 is carcinoma in situ, has not spread to lymph nodes and has not spread to other parts of the body (Tis, N0, M0). (2)
See more: 5 stages of nasopharyngeal cancer: detailed assessment and diagnosis.
Stage 1 nasopharyngeal cancer; Stage 2 nasopharyngeal cancer; Stage 3 nasopharyngeal cancer; Stage 4 nasopharyngeal cancer

Does stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer have symptoms?
MSc. Nguyen Tien Sy, Department of Oncology, Tam Anh General Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, said that stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer often has no symptoms. If present, the symptoms may be similar to common ear, nose and throat diseases, so the patient may subjectively ignore it and not go to the hospital for examination.
Symptoms that may occur when the disease is in a more advanced stage include:
Having difficulty swallowing: Obstructed swallowing, painful swallowing, difficult swallowing.; Ear problems: Otitis media, ear pain, ringing in the ears or worse hearing, ear discharge.; Throat problems: Persistent sore throat that does not go away on its own, may be accompanied by a persistent cough.; Prolonged nasal discharge: Continuous nasal congestion, nosebleeds, unresponsive to conventional treatment.; Headache: Continuous, dull, diffuse pain that does not respond to regular painkillers.
Signs of stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer, if present, will often be similar to symptoms of common ear, nose and throat diseases.
Most cases of stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer are often discovered accidentally when examined for other diseases. Or detected during screening on high-risk subjects such as men, history of HPV, EBV virus infection, family members with nasopharyngeal cancer, habit of using a lot of alcohol, tobacco...

Is stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer dangerous?
According to MSc. Nguyen Tien Sy, treatment of stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer usually has good results, with a 5-year survival rate of over 82%.
In general, having cancer means being in a dangerous situation, so patients should not be negligent in treatment and re-examination to control cancer.

How to diagnose nasopharyngeal cancer
Commonly used methods of screening and diagnosing nasopharyngeal cancer include:
Ask for medical history
The doctor will ask about the patient's and family's history, including lifestyle issues, diet, and other factors that may increase the risk of developing nasopharyngeal cancer.
Examination of the head and neck area
The doctor will feel for any suspicious cervical lymph nodes to detect abnormal locations.
Ear, nose and throat endoscopy
If a suspicious lesion is detected, the doctor may perform a biopsy to obtain a tissue sample. This tissue sample will be evaluated by pathologists to detect cancer cells.
Computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head and neck
This method is indicated to evaluate local tumor characteristics and regional lymph node metastasis.
PET-CT, or CT of other areas of the body
This technique can be used to evaluate whether the tumor has metastasized to other organs or not.

How to treat stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer?
MSc. Nguyen Tien Sy said that stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer has a very high chance of being cured. Proactively going to the doctor when you see unusual signs, or proactively screening high-risk patient groups can help detect the disease at an early stage.
Delaying treatment causes the disease to progress to more severe stages, with a poorer prognosis and increased treatment costs.
Radiation therapy is a treatment for early-stage nasopharyngeal cancer. At this stage, although the cancer has not metastasized to nearby lymph nodes, these nodes often still need radiotherapy. Because these lymph nodes may have metastasized cancer cells but cannot be detected during examination nor can they be detected on CT/MRI images.
Without radiation therapy, cancer cells in the lymph nodes will continue to grow and may spread to other organs.
During treatment, patients need to follow the specialist's instructions. At the end of treatment, patients need to comply with the follow-up appointment. Abandonment of treatment or combination with folk methods of unknown mechanism makes nasopharyngeal cancer progress more seriously.
“Patients should not follow any diet without a doctor's prescription. Because improper dieting can cause nutritional deficiencies, making the body not strong enough to fight disease. Lack of nutrition can also make it impossible for the patient to follow the expected treatment regimen properly and fully", M.D. Nguyen Tien Sy emphasized.
You need to eat a diverse, nutritious diet. You should not eat foods and drinks that are harmful to your health such as alcohol, cigarettes, soft drinks, and stimulants. It is necessary to avoid foods that can irritate the throat mucosa leading to swelling and coughing, such as foods that are too spicy, too hot, too greasy, etc.
Patients should maintain daily work, regularly exercise and exercise at a moderate level; You can choose suitable activities such as walking, yoga, playing table tennis, swimming, cycling...
An issue that receives little attention, but has a very important impact on the treatment process, is that the patient should maintain an optimistic mental state and not be too stressed. You need to proactively talk and share with relatives, friends... to get help and more motivation to overcome the crisis period when you know you have a serious disease. Encouragement and support from relatives will help the patient have confidence in the treatment process.
Patients with stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer need to drink a variety of nutrients, not diet
To consult and schedule a nasopharyngeal cancer screening examination at Tam Anh General Hospital, you can contact:
Stage 0 nasopharyngeal cancer has a high cure rate, but the disease can still recur. Therefore, MSc. Nguyen Tien Sy recommends that continued monitoring after treatment is extremely necessary to prevent nasopharyngeal cancer from recurring.
